comment.author: 18004624@N00
comment._content: So what work is the horse and buggy doing, when the tractor seems to be making such good progress in the field?

comment.author: 10213344@N07
comment._content: I think the tractor is actually plowing or tilling up the earth. The horse is pulling a seeding machine to drop corn into the rows just tilled. At least that is the way I see if when I enlarge the photo.

comment.author: 23393335@N06
comment._content: Those are mules, I think, based on their ears, and the fact that lots of mules were used in this part of the country.

comment.author: 9579695@N07
comment._content: These comments are so funny;  really illustrates the difference between the times!

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Looks like a sizeable river for the area -- I'd guess the Holston, maybe the French Broad.  With all the TVA work in east Tennessee since 1940, there's a good chance this farm is at the bottom of a lake today.

comment.author: 7918375@N04
comment._content: Bet there were no genetically modified corn seeds planted here! I don't want to go backwards, but I sure don't like what I see going forward.

comment.author: 85865635@N00
comment._content: Those are definitely mules.  Yes, *artpease* the ears are a dead giveaway; and they are pulling a corn drill.
